# Draft:Najd revolution__disambig_2

Background
After the fall of the First Saudi State in 1818 at the hands of Ottoman forces led by Ibrahim Pasha, the Ottoman Empire attempted to impose direct control over the Najd region. This caused widespread resentment among the local population, leading to the outbreak of the Najd Revolt in 1819.
Revolt
The Najd rebels, composed of local tribes and supporters of the previous Saudi regime, rose up against Ottoman authority. The revolt was met with a military response from Ibrahim Pasha's forces. Despite resistance from the Najdis, the Ottomans successfully suppressed the uprising.
Aftermath
The suppression of the revolt reinforced Ottoman control over Najd for a short period. It also delayed the re-establishment of Saudi rule until the emergence of the Second Saudi State in the 1820s under Turki bin Abdullah Al Saud.
